text: the latest attacks in Jakarta come after
six years of relative calm in Indonesia
though the problem of militancy has
never truly gone away one of the most
active groups in recent times has been
Jamar Islamia which has its roots in the
anti-colonial struggle against the Dutch
ji was behind the most well known attack
in Bali in 2002 which killed over 200
people including 88 Australians since
then it's targeted high-profile
locations such as embassies and hotels
attacks aimed at foreigners but ended up
mainly killing Indonesians a splinter
group is thought to be responsible for
the 2009 Jakarta hotel bombings which
killed seven people
since then attacks have lessened some
attribute this to increased
counter-terror measures by the
government which has received funding
from Australia and the US but Indonesia
has also been criticized for allowing
its prisons to become incubators for
militancy in August 2014 the former
spiritual head of ji Abu Bakr Bashar
released a message pledging allegiance
to is from inside his prison cell
a pledge he later retracted
